awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Conformational Control of pi-Conjugated Polymeric Materials through Dynamic Bonds.
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project aims to investigate the fundamental correlation between the geometry of electrically semiconducting polymer molecules and their corresponding materials properties.  Most polymeric molecules possess structural flexibility at the nanometer and subnanometer scales, which leads to various 3D shapes that they can adopt. Such geometric variability impacts a wide range of polymer properties that are important for their applications, especially those related to electronic and optical properties. Precision control of the molecular shapes of semiconducting polymers, however, has been a long-standing scientific challenge. This CAREER project tackles this problem by synthesizing molecules with reversible and controllable interactions between different segments along the polymer chain. Through this approach, planarized geometries of these polymer molecules can be enforced and disrupted on demand, leading to tailored properties as a result of the switchable molecular shapes. Establishment of this structural control may not only enable the access of improved functional performance, but also allow for feasible processing of polymer materials into application-relevant forms. In addition, the knowledge gained in this project will advance fundamental understanding in materials-related sciences and benefit multiple research disciplines and STEM education. The educational component of this program focuses on connecting scientific concepts and real-world personal knowledge for the students through relevant experiments in the lab and immersive learning experiences. The societal impacts of this project include benefits from scientific publications, new course components, educational software, and trained STEM students for academia and industry.



TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This program integrates research, education, and outreach activities under the overarching theme of functional polymer materials. Through a synergistic approach combining chemical synthesis, process engineering, and materials characterization, the research project seeks to establish clear fundamental correlations between controlled torsional conformation and materials properties of pi-conjugated systems. This plan is driven by the underlining hypothesis that active control over torsional conformation can significantly impact polymer properties and processability.  The key strategy to achieve this objective is the incorporation of controllable intramolecular dynamic bonds into polymer backbones. A systematic design principle to the synthesis and process engineering of such polymers will be developed on the basis of theoretical simulations and experimental feedback. Structure-property relationships of these materials will be investigated through iterative design-test-feedback-optimization cycles. The ultimate goal is to draw a clear structure-property correlation and to establish design principles for tailoring the integrated properties of conjugated polymeric materials. In parallel, educational and outreach activities are planned to enhance chemistry and broad STEM learning outcome synergistically with the research program. The pedagogical focus is to make the essential connections between scientific knowledge and real-life experiences for the next generation of STEM students through an integrated plan combining course development, undergraduate research programs and outreach activities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project has been conducted to investigation the fundamental correlation between the geometry of electrically semiconducting polymer molecules and their corresponding materials properties, such as how feasible it is to process them into useful forms, optical appearances, and electronic conductivity. The research project involves synthesizing polymers with reversible and controllable interactions between different segments along the polymer chain, and investigating various properties of the polymer by controlling these interactions. Through these approaches, planarized geometries of these polymer molecules are enforced and disrupted on demand, leading to tailored properties as a result of the switchable molecular shapes. Specifically, the research team installed two type of interactions onto polymeric molecules to control the geometry of these lager polymer molecules. One type are the relatively weaker hydrogen bonds. The researchers demonstrated that by forming and breaking hydrogen bonds in a controllable manner, it is made possible to transform polymeric material into desired forms of thin film, and to deposit them as multiple layers of thin film (Figure 1a), which has been a big challenge before. Excellent conductivity was also achieved by using this method because the hydrogen bonds can enforce the molecule to adopt a shape and packing mode that favors electrical conductivity (Figure 1b). The other type of interactions are the relatively stronger boron-nitrogen coordinate bonds. The incorporation of these coordinate bonds led to the formation of a whole new class of materials that possess several unique advantages, such as high stability and tailorable multi-color switching ability under the control of external electrical input (Figure 1c). These results established new methods to impart desirable optical and electrical properties into polymeric materials in a controllable and feasible manner.

 

Overall, this project advanced our ability to tailor and to actively control the properties of semiconducting polymers in both terms of chemical structure design and engineering. These research outcomes provided important new knowledge in the academic fields of polymer chemistry, organic chemistry, materials science, and polymer engineering, which have been widely employed by peers in these international research communities. The 7 peer-reviewed research articles published based on this project have been cited for over 150 times so far. The advances made directly and indirectly in this project lead to better design of polymeric materials and useful new methods to produce polymeric materials to advance the quality of life and efficiency of industrial processes of our society.

 

This project provided valuable research training opportunities for 7 graduate students and 8 undergraduate students, and made significant impacts on preparing these students for their future STEM careers. In addition, a local high school teacher had the opportunity to work at Texas A&M University (TAMU) to design and develop contents for educational outreach programs.

 

The educational innovations of this project include the development of an undergraduate organic laboratory experiment on hydrogen bonded dye molecules (Figure 2), 3-dimensional virtual reality demonstration of common molecules, polymers and inorganic crystals for local children and grade schoolers in the annual Chemistry Open House of TAMU (Figure 3), and the establishment of a Chemistry Summer Camp at TAMU on the theme of light-matter interactions (Figure 4). These educational and outreach activities provided engaging scientific experiences for thousands of students and children. These activities will be maintained after the conclusion of this project and will keep impacting more youths beyond this funding period.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Lei Fang
